elements.content: Pyridyl-substituted oxalamides, L1 (4-pyCH2NHCOCONHCH2py-4), L2 (3-pyCH2NHCOCONHCH2py-3), and L3 (2-pyCH2NHCOCONHCH2py-2), with HgI2 and/or CuBr2, form three new supramolecular complexes, [Hg3L1I6] ∞ (1), {[Cu2(L2)4Br2]·Br2·4H2O}∞ (2), and [Hg(L3)2I2] ∞ (3), respectively. The complexes 1−3 are aligned by the oxalamide−oxalamide N−H···O hydrogen bonds between layers, and their crystal structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 forms a two-dimensional (2D) zigzag sheet architecture extending along the c-direction bridged by L1 ligand and HgI2. Complex 2 forms an interesting planar 2D (4,4) network with the uncoordinated Br− anions and H2O molecules located in the cavities. Complex 3 forms [2 + 2] metallomacrocycles, which are linked with the μ2-bridged I atom and stacked together by intermolecular oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen bonds and by edge-to-face π-stacking between the pyridyl rings to form the desired supramolecular tubular structure along the a-axis. After the removal of the solvent molecules, solid 2 exhibits a permanent porosity verified by a N2 sorption isotherm with a N2 uptake of approximately 1258 cm3/g (STP) and a Langmuir surface area of 2102 m2/g.

The complexes 1-3 are aligned by the oxalamide-oxalamide N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between layers, and their crystal structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 forms a two-dimensional (2D) zigzag sheet architecture extending along the c-direction bridged by L1 ligand and HgI2. Complex 3 forms [2 + 2] metallomacrocycles, which are linked with the μ2-bridged I atom and stacked together by intermolecular oxalamide-oxalamide hydrogen bonds and by edge-to-face π-stacking between the pyridyl rings to form the desired supramolecular tubular structure along the a-axis. After the removal of the solvent molecules, solid 2 exhibits a permanent porosity verified by a N2 sorption isotherm with a N2 uptake of approximately 1258 cm3/g (STP) and a Langmuir surface area of 2102 m2/g.

elements.content: Three different coordination complexes, 1–3, with bis(pyridyl) ligands have been prepared and structurally characterized. The complexes are aligned by the oxalamide−oxalamide N−H···O hydrogen bonds between layers. By comparing the structures of the three complexes, it is clear that the conformations of ligands in the complexes are related to the position of the nitrogen atom.
elements.clean_text: Three different coordination complexes, 1-3, with bis(pyridyl) ligands have been prepared and structurally characterized. The complexes are aligned by the oxalamide-oxalamide N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between layers. By comparing the structures of the three complexes, it is clear that the conformations of ligands in the complexes are related to the position of the nitrogen atom.

elements.content: Recently, the synthesis and characterization of various self-assembled hybrid organic−inorganic macrocyclic or polymeric compounds has received considerable attention because of their potential applications in magnetism, electrical conductivity, ion exchange, separation, catalysis, and porous materials. A porous coordination polymer has a metal−organic framework with open channels where the guest species can be removed and reintroduced reversibly without collapse of the framework. Open metal−organic frameworks derived from robust porous coordination polymers are widely regarded as promising materials for applications in heterogeneous catalysts, sensors, and storage and separation devices. In fact, robust porous frameworks can be formed from the three-dimensional (3D) linkages of coordination bonds or interdigitation of two-dimensional (2D) networks of coordination bonds. They are further evolving from a stage of zeolite mimicry to the creation of new functions characteristic of molecularly inorganic−organic hybrid materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, the synthesis and characterization of various self-assembled hybrid organic-inorganic macrocyclic or polymeric compounds has received considerable attention because of their potential applications in magnetism, electrical conductivity, ion exchange, separation, catalysis, and porous materials. A porous coordination polymer has a metal-organic framework with open channels where the guest species can be removed and reintroduced reversibly without collapse of the framework. Open metal-organic frameworks derived from robust porous coordination polymers are widely regarded as promising materials for applications in heterogeneous catalysts, sensors, and storage and separation devices. In fact, robust porous frameworks can be formed from the three-dimensional (3D) linkages of coordination bonds or interdigitation of two-dimensional (2D) networks of coordination bonds. They are further evolving from a stage of zeolite mimicry to the creation of new functions characteristic of molecularly inorganic-organic hybrid materials.

elements.content: Ligands containing one or more amide functionalities have proved to be useful in self-assembly because they give predictable patterns of hydrogen bonding that can add extra dimensionality and helicity to the supramolecular structures. The self-assembly of these ligands with various transition metal salts (such as those of Zn, Cu, Cd, and Ag) results in the following structures: one-dimensional (1D) chain, zigzag, helical, ladder, 2D square grid, rectangular grid, herringbone, brickwall, bilayer, and 3D cubical, diamondoid, and so on. The oxalamides are diamides of oxalic acid and also superb hydrogen-bonding molecules. Symmetrical disubstituted oxalamides have a Ci symmetry and form α-networks of the P1̅ rod group symmetry. The resulting networks, with each molecule donating and receiving two hydrogen bonds, have a characteristic intermolecular spacing of 5.05 Å.
elements.clean_text: Ligands containing one or more amide functionalities have proved to be useful in self-assembly because they give predictable patterns of hydrogen bonding that can add extra dimensionality and helicity to the supramolecular structures. The self-assembly of these ligands with various transition metal salts (such as those of Zn, Cu, Cd, and Ag) results in the following structures: one-dimensional (1D) chain, zigzag, helical, ladder, 2D square grid, rectangular grid, herringbone, brickwall, bilayer, and 3D cubical, diamondoid, and so on. The oxalamides are diamides of oxalic acid and also superb hydrogen-bonding molecules. Symmetrical disubstituted oxalamides have a Ci  symmetry and form α-networks of the P1̅ rod group symmetry. The resulting networks, with each molecule donating and receiving two hydrogen bonds, have a characteristic intermolecular spacing of 5.05 Å.

elements.content: Mercuric iodide, with most distinguishing physical and electronic properties, has recently been the focus of many studies because of its important utility in fields such as optical detectors and superconducting materials. On the other hand, so far, there have been many examples of obtaining hollow, tubular structures, which are mainly constructed from cyclic oligoureas, cyclic peptides, cyclodextrin-based polyionic amino acids, and calix[4]hydroquinone. However, less attention has been paid to the formation of coordination nanotubes by both hydrogen-bonded and coordination assembly systems of acyclic molecules. Recently, we have reported two interesting [2 + 2] rectangular macrocyclic structures obtained by a flexible ligand L consisting of an azobenzene group and an amide functionality (L = 2-py-CH2NHOCPhNNPhCONHCH2-py-2, py = pyridine) with Cu(II). As an extension of our study on the construction of a new organic−inorganic hybrid, HgI2 was selected for our assembled systems. In this paper, we report three new supramolecular polymeric frameworks, [Hg3L1I6] ∞ (1), {[Cu2(L2)4Br2]·Br2·4H2O}∞ (2), and [Hg(L3)2I2] ∞ (3), which are constructed from pyridyl-substituted oxalamides (Chart ), L1 (L1 = 4-pyCH2NHCOCONHCH2py-4), L2 (L2 = 3-pyCH2NHCOCONHCH2py-3), and L3 (L3 = 2-pyCH2NHCOCONHCH2py-2), with HgI2 and/or CuBr2. Herein, we describe the synthesis of the complexes 1–3, their crystal structures, and the sorption property of 2.

On the other hand, so far, there have been many examples of obtaining hollow, tubular structures, which are mainly constructed from cyclic oligoureas, cyclic peptides, cyclodextrin-based polyionic amino acids, and calix[4]hydroquinone. However, less attention has been paid to the formation of coordination nanotubes by both hydrogen-bonded and coordination assembly systems of acyclic molecules. Recently, we have reported two interesting [2 + 2] rectangular macrocyclic structures obtained by a flexible ligand L consisting of an azobenzene group and an amide functionality (L = 2-py-CH2NHOCPhNNPhCONHCH2-py-2, py = pyridine) with Cu(II). As an extension of our study on the construction of a new organic-inorganic hybrid, HgI2 was selected for our assembled systems. In this paper, we report three new supramolecular polymeric frameworks, [Hg3L1I6] ∞  (1), {[Cu2(L2)4Br2]⋅Br2⋅4H2O}∞ (2), and [Hg(L3)2I2] ∞  (3), which are constructed from pyridyl-substituted oxalamides (Chart ), L1 (L1 = 4-pyCH2NHCOCONHCH2py-4), L2 (L2 = 3-pyCH2NHCOCONHCH2py-3), and L3 (L3 = 2-pyCH2NHCOCONHCH2py-2), with HgI2 and/or CuBr2. Herein, we describe the synthesis of the complexes 1-3, their crystal structures, and the sorption property of 2.

The ligands L1−L3 were prepared as described in a previous publication. The other starting materials were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The elemental analyses were performed on a Heraeus Chn-Rapid elemental analyzer. The infrared spectra were recorded on a Pekin-Elmer 2000 spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pallets. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out with a Rigaku D/max-2500 instrument using a filtered Cu Kα radiation. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms at 77 K were recorded with an accelerated surface area and porosimetry analyzer (ASAP 2010, Micromeritics, USA). The crystals were degassed to a pressure of 6 Pa at 423 K prior to the adsorption measurements. This degassing procedure, which includes both the application of heat and vacuum, ensures the removal of water and any other gas and/or volatile contaminants from the samples. The surface area and the distribution of pore volume (accessible to nitrogen) were calculated with the ASAP 2010 software, by implementing the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller and the Barret−Joyner−Halenda methods, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The ligands L1-L3 were prepared as described in a previous publication. The other starting materials were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The elemental analyses were performed on a Heraeus Chn-Rapid elemental analyzer. The infrared spectra were recorded on a Pekin-Elmer 2000 spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pallets. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out with a Rigaku D/max-2500 instrument using a filtered Cu Kα radiation. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms at 77 K were recorded with an accelerated surface area and porosimetry analyzer (ASAP 2010, Micromeritics, USA). The crystals were degassed to a pressure of 6 Pa at 423 K prior to the adsorption measurements. This degassing procedure, which includes both the application of heat and vacuum, ensures the removal of water and any other gas and/or volatile contaminants from the samples. The surface area and the distribution of pore volume (accessible to nitrogen) were calculated with the ASAP 2010 software, by implementing the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller and the Barret-Joyner-Halenda methods, respectively.

elements.content: A solution of L1 (12 mg) in 3 mL of DMF was slowly mixed with a solution of HgI2 (32 mg) in 10 mL of MeOH. The resulting mixture was left standing for several days to give a colorless crystalline product in a yield of 56% based on Hg(II). Anal. Calcd (%) for C14H14Hg3I6N4O2: C, 10.29; H, 0.86; N, 3.43. elements.content: The diffraction data for 1–3 were collected on a Rigaku RAXISRAPID automated diffractometer at room temperature using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (α = 0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods and successive difference maps (SHELXS 97) and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 by using all unique data (SHELXL 97). Hydrogen atoms were placed in the ideal positions except for those in the solvent−water molecules in 2. The crystal data and experimental details for the crystals of 1–3 are given in Table . The hydrogen bond metrics are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection, Structure Determination, and Refinement

The diffraction data for 1-3 were collected on a Rigaku RAXISRAPID automated diffractometer at room temperature using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (α = 0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods and successive difference maps (SHELXS 97) and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 by using all unique data (SHELXL 97). Hydrogen atoms were placed in the ideal positions except for those in the solvent-water molecules in 2. The crystal data and experimental details for the crystals of 1-3 are given in Table . The hydrogen bond metrics are given in Table .

The solubility of insoluble salts has a critical impact on the synthesis of the related complexes. Several strategies have been employed to circumvent this practical problem. The formation of a I3 − complex may increase the solubility of iodides greatly via the addition of KI or NaI in excess. In addition, the search for and the utilization of appropriate solvent is required. In the synthesis of HgI2 polymeric species, methanol has been proven to be an efficient solvent, and the reaction of the bis-monodentate ligand with HgI2 in a DMF−MeOH mixture can easily result in HgI2 coordination polymers. Thus, in this experiment, L1 and L3 were dissolved in DMF for the synthesis of 1 and 3, whereas L2was dissolved in EtOH for the synthesis of 2. In addition, for the synthesis of 1, the excess of HgI2 does not lead to a 1D zigzag chain structure but rather to a 2D zigzag sheet architecture.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

The solubility of insoluble salts has a critical impact on the synthesis of the related complexes. Several strategies have been employed to circumvent this practical problem. The formation of a I3 - complex may increase the solubility of iodides greatly via the addition of KI or NaI in excess. In addition, the search for and the utilization of appropriate solvent is required. In the synthesis of HgI2 polymeric species, methanol has been proven to be an efficient solvent, and the reaction of the bis-monodentate ligand with HgI2 in a DMF-MeOH mixture can easily result in HgI2 coordination polymers. Thus, in this experiment, L1 and L3 were dissolved in DMF for the synthesis of 1 and 3, whereas L2was dissolved in EtOH for the synthesis of 2. In addition, for the synthesis of 1, the excess of HgI2 does not lead to a 1D zigzag chain structure but rather to a 2D zigzag sheet architecture.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 3 were synthesized by the slow diffusion of a methanolic solution of HgI2 into the DMF solution of L1 or L3 to give small colorless crystals, which were formulated as [Hg3L1I6] ∞ (1) or [Hg(L3)2I2] ∞ (3), on the basis of the elemental analysis. Compound 2 was synthesized by the slow diffusion of an ethanolic solution of L2 into the aqueous solution of CuBr2 to give green crystals, which were formulated as {[Cu2(L2)4Br2]·Br2·4H2O}∞ (2). The compounds 1–3 were very stable in air at ambient temperature and were almost insoluble in common solvents such as water, alcohol, acetonitrile, chloroform, acetone, and toluene. The X-ray crystal-structure analyses at 293 K revealed that compounds 1–3 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/c, the monoclinic space group P2/c, and the triclinic space group P1̅, respectively (Table ).
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1 and 3 were synthesized by the slow diffusion of a methanolic solution of HgI2 into the DMF solution of L1 or L3 to give small colorless crystals, which were formulated as [Hg3L1I6] ∞  (1) or [Hg(L3)2I2] ∞  (3), on the basis of the elemental analysis. Compound 2 was synthesized by the slow diffusion of an ethanolic solution of L2 into the aqueous solution of CuBr2 to give green crystals, which were formulated as {[Cu2(L2)4Br2]⋅Br2⋅4H2O}∞ (2). The compounds 1-3 were very stable in air at ambient temperature and were almost insoluble in common solvents such as water, alcohol, acetonitrile, chloroform, acetone, and toluene. The X-ray crystal-structure analyses at 293 K revealed that compounds 1-3 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/c, the monoclinic space group P2/c, and the triclinic space group P1̅, respectively (Table ).

elements.content: The powder XRD patterns of 1–3 and the patterns simulated on the basis of 1–3 single-crystal structures are presented in Figure . The diffraction peaks in both patterns match each other well in position, indicating the phase purity of the samples as synthesized. In addition, for 2, the XRD patterns (2′) of the solvated forms are similar to those of the desolvated forms (2′′), which indicates that no phase transformation is taking place between them.
elements.clean_text:
XRD Spectra

The powder XRD patterns of 1-3 and the patterns simulated on the basis of 1-3 single-crystal structures are presented in Figure . The diffraction peaks in both patterns match each other well in position, indicating the phase purity of the samples as synthesized. In addition, for 2, the XRD patterns (2') of the solvated forms are similar to those of the desolvated forms (2''), which indicates that no phase transformation is taking place between them.

elements.content: Figure shows a 2D zigzag sheet architecture extending along the c-direction bridged by L1 ligand and HgI2. As shown in Figure a, the central oxalamide core of the ligand L1 in 1 is nearly linear with the donor groups in a trans arrangement. One L1 ligand is alternatively linked with three HgI2 molecules. For the Hg(2) atom in the middle bridged HgI2, the Hg(II) center, being located at a crystallographical inversion center, is tetra-coordinated by four I atoms, two of them from two HgI2 molecules of the adjacent chains. The four Hg−I bond lengths are 2.592(12), 2.592(12), 3.544(11), and 3.544(11) Å, and the six I−Hg−I bond angles are 86.09, 86.09, 93.91, 93.91, 180.00, and 180.00°; thus, four I and one Hg(II) form a HgI4 plane, and the Hg(II) center exhibits a square geometry. For the adjacent Hg(1) atom, the Hg(II) center coordinates with one pyridyl N donor of one L1 ligand and three I atoms, one of them from the middle HgI2 molecule. The Hg atom is arranged in a severely distorted tetrahedron with three Hg−I bonds (2.6555(10), 2.6150(10), and 3.333(11) Å) and one Hg−N bond (2.415(9) Å). The bond angles of I−Hg−I are 93.82(4), 152.79(4), and 90.35(3)°, and those of N−Hg−I are 101.85(3), 103.36(3), and 103.08(3)°; these angles are similar to those observed in the reported Hg(II) complexes with N and I donors (except for three of the Hg−I bond lengths (3.333(11), 3.544(11), and 3.544(11) Å), which are longer than the reported values). In the solid-state structure of polymer 1 (Figure b), the polymeric chains are parallel to each other. There is one kind of hydrogen bond between the chains: N(2)−H···O(1), where the N(2) atom is from one carboxamide group and the O(1) atom is from another carboxamide group. The distances of N−H, H···O, and N···O are 0.86, 2.05, and 2.853(12) Å, respectively, and the angle of N−H···O is 155.9°. The neighboring Hg(1)···Hg(1A) separation within the chain is 18.004 Å, and the shortest Hg(1)···Hg(2) distance is only 4.712 Å. The shortest Hg(1)···Hg(1) distance between the adjacent chains is 5.030 Å, which is consistent with other oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen-bonding systems. The two pyridine rings within one ligand are almost parallel to each other. From previous results, we can see that the self-assembly of HgI2 with flexible 4,4′-bipyridine bridging ligands is prone to form a 1D zigzag framework or a double-helical structure with the general formula [HgI2(L)]∞. As a kind of polymer containing flexible bridging blocks, the structure of polymer 1 is similar to those of the [HgI2(L)]∞ complexes mentioned above. Slightly different from those of the [HgI2(L)]∞ complexes mentioned above, the 2D zigzag sheet architecture in 1 is formed through the middle bridged HgI2 and the intermolecular oxalamide hydrogen bonds with the closest Hg(II)−Hg(II) spacing equal to 5.030(1) Å as shown in Figure c. In addition, the layers of 1 pack via a 21 screw axis instead to yield the space group P21/c. Previously, Puddephatt et al. have employed L1 to assemble with two organoplatinum(IV) units, giving rise to a side-by-side polymeric double helix, where the molecules are connected by two amide···amide hydrogen bonds.

Crystal Structure of [Hg3L1I6]∞ (1)

As shown in Figure a, the central oxalamide core of the ligand L1 in 1 is nearly linear with the donor groups in a trans arrangement. One L1 ligand is alternatively linked with three HgI2 molecules. For the Hg(2) atom in the middle bridged HgI2, the Hg(II) center, being located at a crystallographical inversion center, is tetra-coordinated by four I atoms, two of them from two HgI2 molecules of the adjacent chains. The four Hg-I bond lengths are 2.592(12), 2.592(12), 3.544(11), and 3.544(11) Å, and the six I-Hg-I bond angles are 86.09, 86.09, 93.91, 93.91, 180.00, and 180.00°; thus, four I and one Hg(II) form a HgI4 plane, and the Hg(II) center exhibits a square geometry. The Hg atom is arranged in a severely distorted tetrahedron with three Hg-I bonds (2.6555(10), 2.6150(10), and 3.333(11) Å) and one Hg-N bond (2.415(9) Å). The bond angles of I-Hg-I are 93.82(4), 152.79(4), and 90.35(3)°, and those of N-Hg-I are 101.85(3), 103.36(3), and 103.08(3)°; these angles are similar to those observed in the reported Hg(II) complexes with N and I donors (except for three of the Hg-I bond lengths (3.333(11), 3.544(11), and 3.544(11) Å), which are longer than the reported values). The shortest Hg(1)⋅⋅⋅Hg(1) distance between the adjacent chains is 5.030 Å, which is consistent with other oxalamide-oxalamide hydrogen-bonding systems. elements.content: Complex 2 consists of a polymeric 2D layer structure of (4,4) topology {[Cu2(L2)4Br2]2+} ∞ cations, Br− anions, and H2O molecules (Figure ). As shown in Figure a, the central oxalamide core of the ligand L2 in 2 is nearly linear with the donor groups in a trans arrangement, which is similar to the ligand L1 in 1. The Cu(II) ion is located on a crystallographic two-fold axis position equally coordinated to two pairs of N donors from four distinct L2 ligands and two Br− anions. The coordination geometry of Cu(II) can be described as a distorted octahedral coordination sphere with four pyridine N atoms from four L2 ligands lying in the equatorial plane and two Br− anions in the apical position. The bond lengths of Cu(1)−N(1) and Cu(1)−N(1)#2 (symmetry code 2 = −x + 2, y, −z + 3/2) are 2.085(4) Å, and those of Cu(1)−N(3) and Cu(1)−N(3)#2 are 2.064(3) Å. The bond angles of N−Cu−N are 89.80(14), 90.20(14), and 179.8(2)°, respectively, those of N−Cu−Br are 90.10(11), 90.04(11), 89.90(11), and 89.96(11)°, and that of Br−Cu−Br is 180.0°. In 2, each ligand links two Cu(II) ions through two pyridyl N atoms of L2, and each Cu(II) center is bridged to four neighboring Cu(II) ions by L2 to form a centrosymmetric 60-membered [Cu4(L2 ) 4] metallamacrocyclic grid unit (Figure b). In the macrocycle, the distance between adjacent Cu(II) ions is 12.146 Å, and that of the diagonal is 12.718 Å. The metallamacrocyclic unit extends out along the a- and c-directions to form a 2D (4,4) net containing square grids (Figure b), in which the Cu(II) ions are located on two different planes, alternately up and down. It is interesting to point out that the uncoordinated Br− anions and H2O molecules are fixed in the square cavities. In addition, such 2D layers are linked with the μ2-bridged Br atom (Cu−Br−Cu = 180.0°) and stacked together by intermolecular oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen bonds with the closest Cu(II)−Cu(II) distance of ca. 5.363(1) Å, which is twice as much as the bond length of Cu(II)−Br (2.682 Å) and consistent with other oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen-bonding systems (Figure c). The bond length of Cu(II)−Br (2.682 Å) is longer than our recently published result (a bond length of Cu(II)−Br of 2.350 Å). On the other hand, it is also noteworthy that the polymeric 2D layer structure of the (4,4) topology was described in previously reported complexes. The difference from the above results is that the layer−layer hydrogen bonds in 2 affect the overall topology: they have linked the 2D entities into 3D supramolecular networks.

elements.content: Recently, Puddephatt et al. have described a dimeric ring structure obtained by the ligand L2 with [Pd(dppm)(O3SCF3)2]. The ring adopts an extended chair conformation and is anchored in place by the formation of transannular NH···OC hydrogen bonding. Thus, the ring complex is not stacked by intermolecular oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen bonds and does not form the desired supramolecular tubular structure. Reger et al. have also reported that the ligand L2 reacted with EuCl3·6H2O and formed the compound [Eu(L2H)(H2O)2Cl3]Cl, in which the L2 ligand acts as a bridge between the metal centers to form an infinite 1D chain structure, where intermolecular oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen bonds do not participate in building the extended network.
elements.clean_text: Recently, Puddephatt et al. have described a dimeric ring structure obtained by the ligand L2 with [Pd(dppm)(O3SCF3)2]. The ring adopts an extended chair conformation and is anchored in place by the formation of transannular NH⋅⋅⋅OC hydrogen bonding. Thus, the ring complex is not stacked by intermolecular oxalamide-oxalamide hydrogen bonds and does not form the desired supramolecular tubular structure. Reger et al. have also reported that the ligand L2 reacted with EuCl3⋅6H2O and formed the compound [Eu(L2H)(H2O)2Cl3]Cl, in which the L2 ligand acts as a bridge between the metal centers to form an infinite 1D chain structure, where intermolecular oxalamide-oxalamide hydrogen bonds do not participate in building the extended network.

elements.content: It is also interesting to note that the molecular symmetries of the L2 host and Cu(II) guest persist in the system. The oxalamide molecule similarly retains its inversion center, and the Cu(II) has an approximate C 2 symmetry. The combination of a C 2 symmetry element of the Cu(II) ion with the inversion center of the oxalamide L2 generates the P2/c layer group symmetry. This persistence of molecular symmetry has been found in previously studied urea and oxalamide structures.

The oxalamide molecule similarly retains its inversion center, and the Cu(II) has an approximate C 2 symmetry. The combination of a C 2 symmetry element of the Cu(II) ion with the inversion center of the oxalamide L2 generates the P2/c layer group symmetry. This persistence of molecular symmetry has been found in previously studied urea and oxalamide structures.

elements.content: In 3, unlike the L1 in 1 and L2 in 2, the central oxalamide core of the ligand L3 is nearly linear with the donor groups in a cis arrangement, which is different from the description in a previous publication, where the central oxalamide core of the ligand L3 is nearly linear with the donor groups in a trans arrangement. Each ligand links two Hg(II) ions through two pyridyl N atoms of L3, and each Hg(II) center is bridged to another neighboring Hg(II) ion by two L3 ligands to form a [2 + 2] macrocycle (Figure ). The Hg(1)−Hg(1) distance in each macrocycle is 12.097 Å. The crystal structure of 3 shows the formation of extended nanotubular columns along the a-axis. For each Hg atom, the Hg(II) center coordinates with two pyridyl N atoms of two L3 ligands and two I atoms. These Hg atoms are arranged in a severely distorted tetrahedron with two Hg−I bonds (2.6273(9) and 2.6473(9) Å) and two Hg−N bonds (two sorts: 2.647(8) and 2.607(7) Å; 2.710(8) and 2.954(8) Å); these values are in the expected range. These macrocycles are linked with the μ2-bridged I atoms and stacked together by intermolecular oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen bonds and by edge-to-face π-stacking between the pyridyl rings to form the desired supramolecular tubular structure along the a-axis with the closest Hg(II)−Hg(II) distance of ca. 5.072(1) Å, which is consistent with other oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen-bonding systems (Figure b). In addition, the bond angle of Hg−I−Hg is 147.99°, and the oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen-bonding distances range from 2.859(6) to 2.904(7) Å (Table ). Two sorts of N−Hg−N bond angles in each macrocycle are observed with values of 114.25° and 117.25°, respectively. The conformation and the relative orientation of the hollow tubular structure may be better understood from the schematic diagrams in Figure c. Prior to this work, to the best of our knowledge, there is only one example of a similar hollow tubular structure based on N,N′-bis(3-pyridyl)urea with CuSO4. In general, the self-assembly between a bis-monodentate tecton based on two pyridine units and HgX2 leads to the formation of helixes, macrocycles, or 1D zigzag chain structures. In addition, the simplest interlayer packing would be via the simple translation in a third non-orthogonal direction to give the P1̅ space group.

Crystal Structure of [Hg(L3)2I2]∞ (3)

In 3, unlike the L1 in 1 and L2 in 2, the central oxalamide core of the ligand L3 is nearly linear with the donor groups in a cis arrangement, which is different from the description in a previous publication, where the central oxalamide core of the ligand L3 is nearly linear with the donor groups in a trans arrangement. Each ligand links two Hg(II) ions through two pyridyl N atoms of L3, and each Hg(II) center is bridged to another neighboring Hg(II) ion by two L3 ligands to form a [2 + 2] macrocycle (Figure ). The Hg(1)-Hg(1) distance in each macrocycle is 12.097 Å. The crystal structure of 3 shows the formation of extended nanotubular columns along the a-axis. In addition, the bond angle of Hg-I-Hg is 147.99°, and the oxalamide-oxalamide hydrogen-bonding distances range from 2.859(6) to 2.904(7) Å (Table ). (b) In the stack of 3, the molecules are aligned in a parallel fashion and participate in contiguous backbone−backbone oxalamide−oxalamide N−H···O hydrogen bonding, making a string of hydrogen bonds on either side of the stack, leading to the generation of an extended, open-ended tubular structure with a hollow interior. All hydrogen bonds have distances of 2.866(6)–2.900(7) Å. The inter-ring distance (the distance at which the subunit repeats itself in the nanotube) is 5.072(1) Å. The intermolecular hydrogen bonds are omitted for clarity. (c) Schematic representation of supramolecular tubular structure of 3.

elements.content: Previously, Kang et al. reported that the assembly of the ditopic N-donor ligands bpy, bpe, or dapm and the building block [Cu(trans-oxpy)Cu]2+ (H2oxpy = L3) gave rise to three 1D chain polymers [Cu2(trans-oxpy)(bpy)(H2O)2] n [NO3]2 n ·nH2O (bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine), [Cu2(trans-oxpy)(bpe)(H2O)2] n [NO3]2 n ·3nH2O (bpe = 1,2-di-4-pyridylethylene), and [Cu2(trans-oxpy)(dapm)2] n [NO3]2 n ·6nH2O (dapm = 4,4′-diaminodiphenylmethane), where the ligand L3 adopts the trans conformation. In addition, Puddephatt et al. reported that a 1D zigzag polymer, where the interamide group hydrogen bonds do not participate in the self-assembly, was obtained by coupling two organoplatinum(IV) units, having carboxylic acid groups appended to one of the alkylplatinum groups, through bridging bis(pyridyl) ligands L3.

In addition, Puddephatt et al. reported that a 1D zigzag polymer, where the interamide group hydrogen bonds do not participate in the self-assembly, was obtained by coupling two organoplatinum(IV) units, having carboxylic acid groups appended to one of the alkylplatinum groups, through bridging bis(pyridyl) ligands L3.

elements.content: To evaluate the porosity of the framework of 2, we performed N2 gas sorption isotherm measurements (Figure ) on the desolvated crystalline sample at 77 K. The powder XRD pattern (Figure ) showed the framework of the desolvated sample remained unchanged. It showed a rare type III gas sorption behavior, an abrupt rise at P/P 0 = 0.12, and a N2 uptake of approximately 1258 cm3/g (STP). By assuming a monolayer coverage of N2 and applying the Langmuir model, we find the apparent Langmuir surface area to be 2102 m2/g. The extremely high Langmuir surface area and large total pore volume strongly support the fact that 2 has a nanoporous structure. Compared with the porous Co(II) coordination polymers based on square grids connected by amide−amide hydrogen bonds reported by Kitagawa, which show no N2 adsorption at 77 K, 2 has a high Langmuir surface area and a large total pore volume. The difference may be due to the following reasons: (1) 2 has more open framework and (2) as mentioned above, in 2, 2D layers are linked with the μ2-bridged Br atom and stacked together by intermolecular oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen bonds to form 1D channels, which are still large enough for the passage of small gas molecules. The exceptional stability and the high porosity of metal−organic frameworks are two important properties of this class of materials.

elements.content: In the present work, three different coordination complexes, 1–3, with bis(pyridyl) ligands (L1, L2, and L3) have been prepared and structurally characterized, giving metal−organic supramolecular architectures. By comparing the structures of the three complexes, it is clear that the conformations of ligands in the complexes are related to the position of the nitrogen atom. Ligands L2 and L3 are much more flexible than L1 and could accommodate any of the known structures (cis or trans arrangement). The central oxalamide cores of the ligands in the present work are nearly linear with the donor groups of L1 and L2 in a trans arrangement in the complexes 1 and 2, and those of L3 are in a cis arrangement in the complex 3. Thus, complex 1 forms a zigzag sheet architecture extending along the c-direction bridged by L1 ligand and HgI2. Furthermore, the 2D layered network in 1 was formed through the middle bridged HgI2 and intermolecular oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen bonds with the closest Hg(II)−Hg(II) spacing equal to 5.030(1) Å. Complex 2 forms an interesting planar 2D (4,4) network with the uncoordinated Br− anions and H2O molecules located in the cavities, in which the Cu(II) lies on an inversion center. Complex 3 forms the [2 + 2] metallomacrocycles, which were linked with the μ2-bridged I atom and stacked together by intermolecular oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen bonds and by edge-to-face π-stacking between the pyridyl rings to form the desired supramolecular tubular structure along the a-axis. This indicates that the conformations and donor sites of the ligands in the complexes may play an important role and that the nature of the ligand is a determining factor in controlling the structural topology of these metal−organic supramolecular architectures, which offers the opportunity to control the coordination networks by ligand modifications. In addition, as expected, the oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen bonds between layers are observed in complexes 1–3 with the closest M(II)−M(II) spacing ranging from 5.030 to 5.363(1) Å, which is consistent with the range given in the literature. Overall, complexes 1–3 show one common feature: the layer−layer N−H···O hydrogen bonds have linked the low-dimensional entities into high-dimensional supramolecular networks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In the present work, three different coordination complexes, 1-3, with bis(pyridyl) ligands (L1, L2, and L3) have been prepared and structurally characterized, giving metal-organic supramolecular architectures. By comparing the structures of the three complexes, it is clear that the conformations of ligands in the complexes are related to the position of the nitrogen atom. Ligands L2 and L3 are much more flexible than L1 and could accommodate any of the known structures (cis or trans arrangement). The central oxalamide cores of the ligands in the present work are nearly linear with the donor groups of L1 and L2 in a trans arrangement in the complexes 1 and 2, and those of L3 are in a cis arrangement in the complex 3. Thus, complex 1 forms a zigzag sheet architecture extending along the c-direction bridged by L1 ligand and HgI2. Furthermore, the 2D layered network in 1 was formed through the middle bridged HgI2 and intermolecular oxalamide-oxalamide hydrogen bonds with the closest Hg(II)-Hg(II) spacing equal to 5.030(1) Å. Complex 2 forms an interesting planar 2D (4,4) network with the uncoordinated Br- anions and H2O molecules located in the cavities, in which the Cu(II) lies on an inversion center. Complex 3 forms the [2 + 2] metallomacrocycles, which were linked with the μ2-bridged I atom and stacked together by intermolecular oxalamide-oxalamide hydrogen bonds and by edge-to-face π-stacking between the pyridyl rings to form the desired supramolecular tubular structure along the a-axis. This indicates that the conformations and donor sites of the ligands in the complexes may play an important role and that the nature of the ligand is a determining factor in controlling the structural topology of these metal-organic supramolecular architectures, which offers the opportunity to control the coordination networks by ligand modifications. In addition, as expected, the oxalamide-oxalamide hydrogen bonds between layers are observed in complexes 1-3 with the closest M(II)-M(II) spacing ranging from 5.030 to 5.363(1) Å, which is consistent with the range given in the literature. Overall, complexes 1-3 show one common feature: the layer-layer N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds have linked the low-dimensional entities into high-dimensional supramolecular networks.

Calculated (1) and experimental (1′) XRD patterns for 1, calculated (2) and experimental (2′) XRD patterns for 2, experimental (2′′) XRD patterns for 2 (desolvated crystalline sample), and calculated (3) and experimental (3′) XRD patterns for 3.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Calculated (1) and experimental (1') XRD patterns for 1, calculated (2) and experimental (2') XRD patterns for 2, experimental (2'') XRD patterns for 2 (desolvated crystalline sample), and calculated (3) and experimental (3') XRD patterns for 3.

cln_elements.content: (a) Crystal structure of 1 with the coordination environment around the Hg(II) center. Hydrogens are omitted for clarity. (b) View down the a-direction in 1 showing a zigzag sheet architecture (2D) extending along the c-direction bridged by L1 ligand and HgI2. (c) The 2D layered network was formed through the middle bridged HgI2 and the intermolecular oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen bonds with the closest Hg(II)−Hg(II) spacing equal to 5.030(1) Å. The intermolecular hydrogen bonds are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Crystal structure of 1 with the coordination environment around the Hg(II) center. Hydrogens are omitted for clarity. (b) View down the a-direction in 1 showing a zigzag sheet architecture (2D) extending along the c-direction bridged by L1 ligand and HgI2. (c) The 2D layered network was formed through the middle bridged HgI2 and the intermolecular oxalamide-oxalamide hydrogen bonds with the closest Hg(II)-Hg(II) spacing equal to 5.030(1) Å. The intermolecular hydrogen bonds are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Cu(II) ions in 2. Hydrogens are omitted for clarity. (b) 2D (4,4) network of 2 with the uncoordinated Br− anions and H2O molecules located in the cavities. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (c) 2D layers in 2 linked with the μ2-bridged Br atom and stacked together by intermolecular oxalamide−oxalamide hydrogen bonds with the closest Cu(II)−Cu(II) distance of ca. 5.363(1) Å. The intermolecular hydrogen bonds are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Coordination environment of Cu(II) ions in 2. Hydrogens are omitted for clarity. (b) 2D (4,4) network of 2 with the uncoordinated Br- anions and H2O molecules located in the cavities. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (c) 2D layers in 2 linked with the μ2-bridged Br atom and stacked together by intermolecular oxalamide-oxalamide hydrogen bonds with the closest Cu(II)-Cu(II) distance of ca. 5.363(1) Å. The intermolecular hydrogen bonds are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: (a) Fragment of the structure of 3. Hydrogens atoms, except for those of the NH groups, are omitted for clarity. (b) In the stack of 3, the molecules are aligned in a parallel fashion and participate in contiguous backbone−backbone oxalamide−oxalamide N−H···O hydrogen bonding, making a string of hydrogen bonds on either side of the stack, leading to the generation of an extended, open-ended tubular structure with a hollow interior. All hydrogen bonds have distances of 2.866(6)–2.900(7) Å. The inter-ring distance (the distance at which the subunit repeats itself in the nanotube) is 5.072(1) Å. The intermolecular hydrogen bonds are omitted for clarity. (c) Schematic representation of supramolecular tubular structure of 3.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Fragment of the structure of 3. Hydrogens atoms, except for those of the NH groups, are omitted for clarity. All hydrogen bonds have distances of 2.866(6)-2.900(7) Å. The inter-ring distance (the distance at which the subunit repeats itself in the nanotube) is 5.072(1) Å. The intermolecular hydrogen bonds are omitted for clarity. (c) Schematic representation of supramolecular tubular structure of 3.
